attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description:
A spot check in the cash office was carried out with the aim of ensuring cash at hand was tallying with that of the cash flow balance.

       It was noted that the cashier fully accounted for the expected cash balance of Ksh 113,794 as at 21/03/2025. At the time of cash count there were IOUs valued at Ksh 17,000.
attributes.recommendation:
The cashier should maintain the controls.

         IOUs should be cleared within a reasonable time frame not waiting for more than two weeks
attributes.effect: Company’s money was adequately safeguarded. However, IOUs were taking time to be cleared
attributes.remediation_plan: No remediation plan as the system currently is working smoothly

value: Cash was well controlled.
Fair controlled. I will be following up to ensure the IOUs are cleared.
In a prior audit report the cashier fully accounted for the expected cash balance.
Current
Cash was well controlled as the branch is using a cashless payment system.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Stock Count
attributes.description:
A physical stock take was conducted on 18.03.2025 with the aim of establishing whether internal controls were effective and whether physical stock items were matching with those in the SAP system.  After stock take, it was noted that most stock items had nil variations with exception to;

  •          Bread stock had +33pieces cumulatively

  •         Poly bags had a variance of +2,095 cumulatively

  •          Wheat bran variance of +1.283 kgs

  •         Crates had a variance of +1

  •         Yeast had a variance of -0.986

·         Details of the findings were as illustrated  in the table below;

 

Crates:

As at the time of stock take, total crate balance in supermarkets, institution and routes was 122 pcs.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should maintain control of stock items by regularly taking stock and making follow ups in case of variances. Branch sales representative should make a follow up so as to verify the crate balance in supermarkets, routes and institutions.
attributes.effect: At the time of stock take, there were controls to safeguard the company’s assets as depicted by minimal variances noted with exception to polybags and crates.
attributes.remediation_plan:
A follow up on crate balance should be done daily by branch manager and any balance should be brought to the branch the following day

To reduce polybags variance, recording should be checked to ensure all stock in/out are done accurately

value: We do make stock follow ups on daily basis so as to ensure physical stock align with what is in the system. The crate balances are in supermarkets. We are doing follow up with the help of the sales representative to reduce the balance.

Stocks in the branch are fairly controlled. The variance in polybags is as a result of the 19 varieties we have meaning an accumulation will result to such variance but we will work to minimize it. A follow up is being made to reduce crate balances.
In a prior audit report dated 04.03.25 bread stock had -79 pieces cumulatively, poly bags had a variance of +519 pieces cumulatively and wheat bran variance of -1.192 kgs
Current
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description: Bread produced and packed in the branch were weighed randomly to determine if bread dispatched to the market was of the correct weight. From the sample selected audit noted that cases of underweight were minimal as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: Spot checks should be enhanced to ensure all production parameters are followed so as to maintain bread weight.
attributes.effect: Underweight bread dispatched to market exposes the company to risk of penalties if they are intercepted by the weight and measures officials
attributes.remediation_plan: Bread weight in the branch was fairly controlled as some varieties had nil cases of underweight. This Trend should be upheld.

value: We will try our best to maintain the required bread weight standards required
Will be taken care of by increasing spot checks.
In a prior audit report cases of underweight were noted as follows; 4ctw-17.3%, 4brw-5%, 6ctw-45.61%, 6brw-24%, 8ctw-40%, 8brw-6% and 1.5ctw-7.69%
Current
As per the samples weighed in the branch, weight was fairly controlled as some varieties had nil underweight cases.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Damages Check
attributes.description:
An analysis of production and market/supermarket damages was done to determine whether they were within the allowed percentage of 0.2% to total production and 0.5% of total sales respectively. 

       A sample period of 19 days (1 to 19 March 2025) was used to analyse bread damages. Audit noted that the percentage of average production damages stood at 0.26% of the total production while average market damages was 0.46% of total sales as illustrated in the table below;

Damages sent to Ingredients

  •         For the same period damages sent to ingredients were less by 8.6kgs
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should control bread damages by ensuring all production procedures are being followed and bread produced is of good quality so as to reduce production.
attributes.effect: Production bread damages were above set limits meaning the company had lost revenue amounting to Ksh 20,437.62 {[(0.06*1,671)/0.26]*53} through excess damages.
attributes.remediation_plan: Production damages could be controlled in the branch by adhering to production procedures and good maintenance of machinery especially ovens

value: We are trying our best to reduce bread damages in the branch by ensuring we produce quality bread.
I will advise the manager and supervisors to ensure all set production procedures are followed so as to reduce cases of damages. During the period our mixer had issues too.
In a prior audit report average production damages stood at 0.23% of the total production while average market damages was 0.41% of total sales
Current
This test check is intended to determine whether the branch was operating within set parameters of 0.2% for production damages and 0.5% of market damages to total production/sales respectively.
From the analysis production damages were above the set limit of 0.2% of total production which implies that there were either lapses in control
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Mixing charts and mixing chart summaries from 12 February 2025 to 20 March 2025 were examined to find out the branch’s utto consumption, average yield, cases of remix and summation of totals

        After examining the records the follow were noted;

  •         Average yield per bag was191.23loaves per bag.

  •          Utto consumption was at 100%.

  •        Average production was 166.22 bags per day representing 85.24% of target which is 195 bags per day (Branch Capacity)

       The table below illustrates the findings;
attributes.recommendation: On those days the branch run on full capacity, the branch management should ensure production target is achieved
attributes.effect: Target production in bags was not achieved meaning the branch’s capacity was underutilized
attributes.remediation_plan: To improve production so as to achieve set target of 195 bags per day, marketing promotions should be done within the existing routes so as to reach to new customers.

value: Production has been affected by low sales during the period.
Average sales order dropped leading to shift cut and control bread balance hence affecting target achievement due to low sales.

In a prior audit report average yield per bag was191.23loaves per bag, utto consumption was at 100% and average production was 162.14 bags per day representing 83.15% of target which is 195 bags per day (Branch Capacity)
Current
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description:
Outstanding debts were analysed as at 22 March 2025 to check the magnitude. It was observed that the customers had outstanding balance of Ksh 351,608.20 while institutions had balances amounting to Ksh 471,725 as illustrated in table I and II respectively below;

                              Route Customers

                                    Institutions
attributes.recommendation: A follow up should be made by sales rep to ensure customers with debt do pay and clear the outstanding balances
attributes.effect: Customers with debts exposes the company to risk of losing its revenue if they do not have security deposit to cover up for the outstanding balances
attributes.remediation_plan:
The company should come up with the following strategies so as to reduce debts;

  • Ensure customers have security deposits

  • Tighten credit checks before extending terms for those customers who have one

  • Set clear credit limits and enforce them.

  • Encourage payment of each day's supply before placing  an order for the next day

  • Those Customers who have not paid and don't have security deposit should not be supplied the following day

  • Allow partial payments or structured repayment plans for those with huge amounts

value: The Sales rep is following up so as the balances are cleared
Communication and follow up is being made with Sales team.
In a prior audit report outstanding debts were analysed as at 16th February 2025 it was noted that total outstanding debt was Ksh 967,459.72.
Current
Analysis of outstanding balances at the branch level as at 22nd March 2025 to determine the magnititude

From the analysis the company is likely to loss:

KES. 13,135 - bread lost when the sales crew were distributing and 

KES. 12,321 - the customers have defaulted in payment
Sales Department

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Production efficiency calculation from 12 February 2025 to 20 March 2025 was done to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.

         It was noted that the average production efficiency was 4.48 bags per production worker as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should allocate production workers as per production target shift wise so as to ensure set efficiency is achieved
attributes.effect: The branch did not achieve the set production efficiency target meaning that the cost of production was above set budget
attributes.remediation_plan: The branch manager and supervisors should allocate production workers shift wise as per the planned bags to be produced because they have branch balance and they have market demand estimates which will guide them.

value: We are trying our best so as to achieve set target of 4.5 bags per production worker. However, slicing machines contributes to low efficiency due changes of blades hence delay in baking tins rotation.
Will put more effort to get production efficiency 4.5 bag per person. Slicing machines contributes to low efficiency due changes of blades hence delay in baking tins rotation.
From prior audit report from 2nd January 2025 to 11th February 2025 average production efficiency was 4.48 bags per production worker
Current

Production efficiency test is done to check if the company's production target per worker is being achieved. Therefore each branch has a set production target which has to be met by production workers hired if there's no machinery breakdown and interruptions.

The branch was slightly below set parameter of 4.48 bags per worker. The branch management should hire production workers as per shift target and ensure that the target is achieved shift wise in case there's no breakdown
Operations/Production Department

The objective of this test is to determine;

  • Efficiency achieved per production worker for the sample period

  • Number of bags produced for the sample period

  • Production Workers hired for the sample period

  • Cost implication if any

  • What made the branch not to achieve set target

attributes.title: Vehicle Mileage and Fuel Consumption analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of fuel consumption was done from 1 to 21 March 2025 to assess whether the standard fuel consumption set for each vehicle was being met

      It was noted that all vehicles’ fuel consumption was within the set standards with exception to Town route vehicle which consumed more fuel.

         Nandi Hills vehicle fuel should be adjusted to match the actual consumption has they had saved fuel.

         The findings have been illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: A follow up with Nandi Hills and Town routes fuel consumption should be rechecked and a retest be done to get the accurate standard rate of fuel consumption.
attributes.effect: Fuel consumption was well controlled with exception to Town route which used more fuel hence an extra cost of distributing bread.
attributes.remediation_plan: Fuel consumption was well controlled. This trend to be maintained

value: We will follow up to ensure the two vehicles fuel is controlled by requesting for retest
Noted, we will follow up to ensure fuel is well controlled by requesting for retest.
Current

This is a test designed to control fuel per route for each vehicle. There  are set parameters or standard of fuel to be consumed in a given number of kilometers which are subject to review in case the current consumption is not matching with what was set.

Fuel consumption was well controlled for the period. A retest for Nandi hills route vehicle KDQ 560Z should be done to come up with the accurate standard rate because currently its doing 7.77Km/L while set standard rate is 7.5Km/L
Transport/Fleet Department

The main objectives of this test are to;

  • Check if set standard rate of consumption is met
  • Check distance cover by vehicles in routes are consistency from one day to another and there are no huge variances
  • Check Vehicles current odometer reading (During visits to branch)
  • Check whether there are fuel savings

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Packing efficiency was calculated from 12 February 2025 to 20 March 2025. The aim was to determine if the packers hired were achieving the set packing efficiency of 97 crates per packer.

         It was noted that the average packing efficiency was 91.52 crates per packer as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: Hiring of Packers shift wise should be guided by the number of bags produced in the prior shift. This will enable the branch to achieve set target
attributes.effect: Average packing efficiency was below the set target and this implies that packing cost was above the set budget hence an extra cost to the company
attributes.remediation_plan: The branch management should hire Packers based on bread produced in prior shift as they will be having an estimate of loaves produced

value:
Packing efficiency was affected by oven breakdown. However, we are trying our best to achieve set target.

        Slicing machines contributes to low efficiency due changes of blades hence causing delays

Will push to get set target for packing efficiency.

         Slicing machines contributes to low efficiency due changes of blades hence causing delays too.
From prior audit report from 2nd January 2025 to 11th February 2025 average packing efficiency was 91.61 crates per packer.
Current
This test is essential so as to control labour charges of packing bread whereby each packer has a set target of crates to be packed in eight hours
From the analysis the company's cost of packing bread was above set budget as the Packers hired for the sample period did not achieve set target
Operations/Production Department
The objective of this test was to test whether the company set standard of crates to be packed by each packer per shift was being attained

attributes.title: Bread Return Analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of all bread retuned to the branch from 1 to 20 March 2025 was done to determine the reasons with corresponding sum of bread returned when converted to 400gms.

      From the analysis a total of 1,787.50 pieces of loaves worth Ksh 94,737.50 (using Minishop price) were returned. Below is the illustration of the reasons for return and pieces of loaves in 400gms;
attributes.recommendation: To control bread returned from the market as a result of deformation, overbaked, short expiry, undersized and ender baked, the branch management should ensure all production procedures are followed and bread with deformities should not be packed
attributes.effect: The company is losing sales revenue when bread is returned to the branch due to reasons which can be controlled during production.
attributes.remediation_plan:
There should be a follow up in production to ensure the set procedures are followed so as to reduce cases of damages or producing substandard bread.

Orders placed should be accurate to ensure supply is as per customer to avoid cases of over supply hence resulting to returns

In case of torn wrapper, these polybags should be set aside and the same communicated to the supplier to check his or her production lines

value: We will make a follow up to ensure bread sent to the market is of good quality so as to reduce returns.

We will try to control production to ensure returns due to quality issues are minimized. Further in some cases the sales crew may categorize reason of return as deformed yet bread is not deformed. Therefore this need to be looked at so that an accurate reason of return is captured.
In a prior audit report, from 1st January 2025 to 14th February 2025 total loaves returned were 3,159 pieces of loaves worth Ksh 167,427 (using Minishop price) were returned.
Current

Some of the returns can be controlled if the production team produces bread of standard quality as most return reasons point to production gaps. Therefore the company is losing revenue from high market returns and same time distribution cost per piece of loaf will go high as those returned were never sold
Sales Department
